doc.content: Five Alaskans have been indicted by a federal grand jury on charges of illegally killing black bears for their gallbladders and other parts prized by buyers in Asia, the U.S. attorney for Alaska said Thursday. The five suspects, all from Anchorage, were involved in two apparently unrelated conspiracies that resulted in at least 14 black bears being taken in 2002 and 2003, federal authorities said. Federal and state law enforcement agencies, meanwhile, are investigating other poaching cases involving as many as 50 other black bears in the state, according to U.S. Attorney Timothy Burgess. Burgess and other officials Thursday declined to give any details about those other 50 bears and who might be under investigation.
